content: Residential energy efficiency benefits consumers by reducing utility bills and supports national environmental goals by decreasing the demand for fossil fuel-generated electricity. Various policies, including tax incentives, have been implemented since the 1970s to promote conservation and energy efficiency. The challenge lies in determining the most effective policy tools for achieving energy efficiency objectives. In recent years, residential energy consumption in the United States has slightly decreased as a percentage of all energy consumption. Per capita residential energy use has also shown modest declines, indicating possible efficiency gains. Residential energy use per capita in the United States has remained relatively constant since the 1970s, with a downward trend starting in the mid- to late-2000s. Efficiency gains have helped keep aggregate residential energy use flat or slightly declining, despite the increasing use of energy-demanding technologies. One policy option to promote residential energy efficiency is through tax credits. The report provides an overview of current residential energy-efficiency tax credits. The report explores the use of tax credits to promote residential energy efficiency by addressing market failures and barriers in the sector. The report discusses the economic rationale for residential energy-efficiency tax incentives to address market failures and barriers in the sector. It outlines how tax incentives correct these issues and provides an economic analysis of primary tax incentives for residential energy efficiency. For the 2017 tax year, taxpayers can claim tax credits for residential energy-efficiency improvements and renewable-energy technologies. The nonbusiness energy property tax credit allows credits for building envelope improvements and high-efficiency heating, cooling, and water-heating systems. The nonbusiness energy property tax credit (IRC §25C) allows taxpayers to claim a tax credit for energy-efficiency improvements to their primary residence's building envelope and high-efficiency heating, cooling, and water-heating appliances. The credit is calculated as 10% of expenditures on improvements plus the cost of each energy-efficient property capped at a specific amount. The Section 25C tax credit allows taxpayers to claim a credit for energy-efficient improvements to their primary residence, including building envelope upgrades and high-efficiency appliances. The credit is calculated as 10% of expenditures on improvements plus the cost of each energy-efficient property, capped at $500. Taxpayers often claim the maximum credit amount for energy-efficient property purchases. The Section 25C tax credit for energy-efficient property is capped at $500, and if claimed before 2017, it cannot be claimed again in 2017 as the credit expired at the end of that year. The residential energy efficient property tax credit (IRC §25D) allows taxpayers to claim a 30% credit for installing renewable energy technologies on their residence. The Section 25D tax credit allows taxpayers to claim a credit for installing renewable energy technologies on their residence. The credit rate is 30% for 2017 and will decrease to 26% in 2020 and 22% in 2021, expiring after that year. The maximum value of the credit is not capped. The Section 25D tax credit for renewable energy technologies decreases from 30% in 2017 to 26% in 2020 and 22% in 2021, expiring after that year. The maximum value of the credit is uncapped.
